attributes.title: RRR: How beliefs change: self-generated results vs. meta-analytic results
attributes.description: An exploration of how scientists update their beliefs about an effect in light of both their own research results and meta-analytic results. The study will sample from laboratories participating in Registered Replication Report projects at Perspectives on Psychological Science.

attributes.title: Poverty and Negativity Bias
attributes.description: A correlational study to test the relationship between socio-economic status and negativity bias

q2.value: Amine Sijilmassi, Coralie Chevallier, Lou Safra

q3.value: Poverty is associated with a cluster of psychological traits such as high time-discounting and impulsivity. These traits are sometimes assumed to stem from an evolutionarily stable strategy that is adaptive in harsh environments. Error management theory predicts that humans are endowed with a negativity bias which may be even more acute in harsh environments. This observational study tests whether a socio-economic gradient exists on the negativity bias – defined here as punishment responsiveness. Our design is a discrimination task with two hardly distinguishable stimuli. We use signal detection theory to evaluate participants’ response bias, which we take as a proxy for negativity bias. We predict that poverty is associated with higher negativity bias.

q4.value:
Our fundamental prediction is that SES is negatively correlated to the response bias. We take response bias as a proxy for negativity bias/punishment responsiveness. To be more precise, we make the following hypotheses:
H1: d’ will increase in each consecutive block as participants become familiar with the task
H2: d’ will increase similarly across quartiles
H3: b will evolve in each subsequent block, as participants learn by reinforcement to avoid the harsh stimulus
H4: Most importantly, the increase in response bias from block to block will be significantly positively correlated with our SES measures
We intend to measure both subjective and objective SES. We predict that both objective and subjective SES are correlated with negativity but make no specific prediction about which is most correlated.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
1)  	Overview:
Our research is an observational study that aims to establish a correlation between socioeconomic status and negativity bias.
To do so, we use a standard signal detection task adapted from Pizzagalli, 2004 and Chevallier et al., 2016. 
2)  	Method
The experiment was designed using the survey platform Qualtrics and will be distributed online using the Prolific distribution platform. We opted for an online experiment to ensure that our sample is as representative as possible of the general population (see Sampling Plan). Moreover, studies demonstrate that the findings of online experiments correlate well with those of traditional lab experiments (Dandurand, F., Shultz, T.R. & Onishi, K.H.,2008).

In our study, our participants are asked to perform a task and answer a questionnaire. The task consists in a succession of signal detection trials during which they must accurately identify the stimulus. We plan to display 300 trials divided in 3 blocks of 100. Blocks are separated by a message indicating progress to the participant.

We use the same stimuli as in Chevallier et al., 2016. They both represent a line within a circle. They only differ in the length of the line: it is either 11.5mm or 13mm long. As in any non-trivial signal detection task, the two stimuli are visually similar and difficult to distinguish, thus creating noise in the detection.
   
In each trial, participants are presented with one of the two stimuli (short or long line) for 700ms and must decide which one they see. Answers are given on the participants’ keyboard. Keyboard attribution has been randomized: in one condition, e is short and p is long, in another condition, the opposite is true. If the participant gives the right answer, they move to the next trial. If not, they risk facing a negative feedback (or punishments).
In this experiment, punishment is the text “-5 pennies” displayed in red and size 48. The punishment is displayed during 1 second before disappearing. The next trial can start after the feedback disappears. Participants can only make two types of error: they can either mistakenly identify a long line or a short line. As in Pizzagalli, 2004 and Chevallier, 2016, punishment on these two mistakes is asymmetrical. The asymmetry has been randomized:
-          In one condition, answering “short” when a “long” line was displayed is punished 75% of the time, whereas the other error was punished 25% of the time.
-          In a second condition, answering “long” when a “short” line was displayed is punished 75% of the time, while the other error was punished 25% of the time.

In both conditions, one type of error is substantially more punished than the other one. We categorize the most punished line as the “harsh” line and the least punished line as the “lenient” line. This asymmetry is assumed to bias the participants’ decision in favor of the lenient line. The amplitude of the response bias serves as a proxy for negativity bias.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
1)      Sample selection
Participants will be recruited using the Prolific platform. Using Prolific is of interest to us for two reasons:
-          Prolific allows us to recruit a sample of the British population that is representative on sex and age
-          Prolific allows us to access a more diverse pool of participants than would have been possible within our lab. Because we want to test the effect of socioeconomic status, we must make sure that our sample comprises enough low income individuals.

All subjects will receive a compensation of 2.50£ for their participation as well as a variable monetary reward depending on task performance. All participants will start with a 50 pennies endowment but will lose 5 pennies every time a negative feedback is displayed to them. Once they have completed the task, they will learn about their remaining bonus on Prolific.

q13.value:
2)      Statistical power

Because the relevance of our study relies heavily on the participation of subjects in a wide array of income distribution, our sample size must guarantee that each quartile is sufficiently represented. 

Our statistical power calculation requires us to recruit at least 36 individuals per quartile ( a total of 144 participants). Moreover, Prolific’s recruitment policy states that a minimum of 300 hundred participants is required to ask for a representative sample of the UK population. Therefore, our sampling method consists in recruiting participants until the threshold has been met for each quartile and our sample size is at least 300. Our sampling effort will last until these two conditions have been achieved.

question.value:
All data about participants and their performance will be recorded using Qualtrics and compiled into a CSV file. We intend to retrieve data from Qualtrics for the following variables: 
SES variables: 
•	Estimated average monthly income
•	Highest achieved degree (6 possible answers)
•	Subjective ranking on the MacArthur ladder scale (scale from 1 to 10)
•	Subjective worry about finances. This will be assessed with three questions. Answers are scaled from 1 (strongly disagree) to 9 (strongly agree)
Task variables:
•	The condition in which the participant has been randomized
•	The trial number
•	The block number
•	The type of image (short or long line) that was displayed during the trial: 1 for short, 0 for long
•	The answer given by the participant during the trial: 1 for short, 0 for long
•	Whether the answer was right (1) or wrong (0)
•	Whether the negative feedback was displayed during the trial (1) or not (0)

We will create one indice for objective SES and one indice for subjective SES. To establish these indices, we first compute the z-score for each collected SES variable. We then simply sum the z-scores for objective SES variables to obtain the first indice and the z-scores for subjective SES to obtain the second indice. 
Objective SES indice = z-score(Income) + z-score(Highest degree)
Subjective SES indice = z-score(Subjective worry about finances) + z-score(MacArthur Ladder)

Every statistical analysis will be performed using the programming language R. All scripts will be made available on the OSF portal.

1)  	Data summary:
The second step of our analysis is to summarize our data. Namely, we are interested in knowing the following basing facts about our data:
-          The average number of displayed negative feedback for each participant
-          The average number of correct answers for each participant
-          The average number of displayed negative feedback and correct answers by block and by stimulus type (short or long line)
This basic overview of our data allows us to ensure that nothing went wrong with data collection.


 
2)  	Compute a measure of negativity bias using signal detection theory:

To use signal detection theory, we will mainly be interested in the proportion of correct answers by stimulus type. We will classify our data into a standard signal detection theory typology:

-          If the lenient stimulus is displayed and the answer was the lenient stimulus, the observation is classified as a “hit”
-          If the lenient stimulus is displayed and the answer was the harsh stimulus, the observation is classified as a “miss”
-          If the harsh stimulus is displayed and the answer was the lenient stimulus, the observation is classified as a “false alarm”
-          If the harsh stimulus is displayed and the answer was the harsh stimulus, the observation is classified as a “correct rejection”


Once we have identified the 4 types of answers for each participant, we can compute accuracy and bias for each participant using SDT methods of calculation:

-          d’ = (1/2)* log((hits * correct rejections) / (misses * false alarms))
-          b = (1/2) * log((hits * false alarms) / (misses * correct rejections))
 

Importantly, we intend to correct our data in cases where participants are 100% accurate for either stimulus. In these cases, we will modify accuracy rate to 98%. This minor change is unlikely to have a significant effect on our results and is yet necessary to compute d’ or b (otherwise we may be dividing by zero). This procedure is the exact same as the one used in Chevallier et al 2016 and is adapted from Hautus MJ., 1995.  (Hautus MJ., 1995 Corrections for extreme proportions and their biasing effects on estimated values ofd′. Behav Res Methods Instrum Comput. 1995;27: 46–51.)


After we have computed d’ and b by participant, we perform the same analysis by block. We then  compute our main variable of interest, which is the overall change of response bias throughout blocks (Δb). Δb is defined as the difference between the response bias for the last block and the first block. Our interpretation is that the higher Δb, the more participants’ behavior has been influenced by negative feedback cues. 

 
4)  	Response bias and SES

The last step of our analysis is to test the correlation between SES and Δb. As in Chevallier et al., 2016 we first run a repeated-measures ANOVA with block as a within-subject factor to test whether response bias changed over time. 
We then examine the relationship between our SES variables and Δb using correlations, a median-split based on participants’ response to the questionnaire. More precisely, we will compute correlations between: 

•	Δb and the objective SES indice
•	Δb and the subjective SES indice

q22.value:
Our analysis plan, including exclusion criteria and variable manipulation, is mostly adapted from Chevallier et al. 2016. 

1.	Exclusion criteria
We will exclude from analysis participants with the following characteristics: 
•	Task accuracy is 2 SD below average
•	Reported total monthly income is 0 or above £12,500
•	Students
•	More than 40% of observations has been removed due to unusual response time (see below)

2.	  Handling outlier observations:
Before engaging in further analysis, we will scrutinize reaction times to identify outliers. The basic idea is that if a participant’s reaction time pattern is unusual, the observation will be removed. We implement a precise procedure for identifying outliers. This procedure is the same as in Chevallier et al, 2016.
-          Trials where the participant’s response time is below 150ms or above 2500ms will be eliminated from data. 
-          We then use a natural log transformation on all observed reaction times (log(RT)). Moreover, we calculate the reaction time’s standard deviation (sd) and mean (m). We only keep observations where: m + 3sd > log(RT) > m – 3sd
-          Finally, we compute and report the percentage of removed outliers. In Chevallier et al, 2016, 3.6% of trials were removed from analysis.

attributes.title: ‘I expected more from you’: the effect of expectation-disconfirmation on employees’ satisfaction with supervisory support
attributes.description: In this study, we are interested in the effect of expectation-disconfirmation on public employees’ satisfaction with frontline supervisors’ supportive leadership. We are interested in both predictive expectations (what supervisors will do) and normative expectations (what supervisors should do).

q1.value: ‘I expected more from you’: the effect of expectation-disconfirmation on employees’ satisfaction with supervisory support

q3.value: In this study, we are interested in the effect of expectation-disconfirmation on public employees’ satisfaction with frontline supervisors’ supportive leadership. We are interested in both predictive expectations (what supervisors will do) and normative expectations (what supervisors should do).

q4.value:
H1: Compared to positive confirmation, positive disconfirmation of predictive (H1a) and normative (H1b) expectations (exceeding expectations) will lead to higher satisfaction with supervisor support. 
H2: Compared to negative confirmation, negative disconfirmation of predictive (H2a) and normative (H2b) expectations (falling short of expectations) will lead to lower satisfaction with supervisor support. 
H3: Disconfirmation of normative expectations will have a stronger effect on satisfaction with supervisor support than disconfirmation of predictive expectations.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Two studies are conducted in order to test our hypotheses. Study 1 will allow us to test the effects of disconfirmation of predictive expectations (hypothesis 1a and 2a). For the design of this study, we follow earlier 2 x 2 factorial experimental designs (Van Ryzin 2013; Grimmelikhuijsen and Porumbescu 2017). Since we are also interested in normative expectations (hypothesis 1b and 2b) and these are generally much harder to manipulate in an experiment, we decided to adopt a quasi-experimental design to test the influence of disconfirmation of normative expectations. This resulted in two studies that are similar with the exception of the phase in which expectations are either manipulated (in the case of predictive expectations) or measured (in the case of normative expectations). The phases of the (quasi-) experiment are described below. A schematic overview of the survey flow is presented in 'Survey flow_preregistration.docx'.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Our hypotheses will be tested based on a quasi-experiment and a 2 x 2 factorial experiment both embedded into one survey. The survey will be sent to a sample which is retrieved from Prolific Academic (www.prolific.ac), which is an online crowdsourcing platform that can be used to collect human subjects for research. Participants receive a small reward for their participation in certain online surveys or experiments. An obvious benefit of this method of recruitment is that it allows the researcher to preselect the sample based on certain (demographic) variables (Grimmelikhuijsen and Porumbescu 2017). However, some concern has been raised about the quality of data that is collected through other online crowd-sourcing platforms, such as Mechanical Turk (MTurk) or Crowdflower (CF). In particular, the lack of naivety of participants is a growing cause for concern. A recent study in which several crowdsourcing platforms in terms of naivety and dishonesty are compared, found that participants from Prolific Academic are less dishonest and more naïve than the more commonly used MTurk (Peer et al. 2017; Palan and Schitter 2018). In addition, the quality of the data from Prolific was highest compared to MTurk and CF. Following the recommendations of this study, we expect Prolific to deliver data that meets the quality standards to test our hypotheses. 
	We will conduct our experiment among employees that work in the educational sector. More specifically, we include teachers in public primary, secondary and higher education (colleges, universities). To keep our vignettes as realistic as possible, it is necessary to take a certain work context into account. In order to make sure all participants can relate to these vignettes equally, only teachers in primary, secondary or higher educations are included in our sample. By making sure our vignettes match the work context of our participants, we increase ecological validity of our experiment (Morton and Williams 2010).

q13.value:
Our target sample size for study 1 is 300 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 350, assuming that not all will complete the total task.
Our target sample size for study 2 is 300 participants.  We will attempt to recruit up to 350, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: We base our target sample size based on earlier studies by Grimmelikhuijsen and Porumbescu (2017).

question.value: The manipulation of variables is described in the documents 'Survey_study1.docx' and 'Survey_study2.docx'.
The measurement of variables is described in the documents 'Survey_study1.docx' and 'Survey_study2.docx'.
We will conduct ANOVA- and/or multiple regression analyses to test our hypotheses.

An obvious benefit of this method of recruitment is that it allows the researcher to preselect the sample based on certain (demographic) variables (Grimmelikhuijsen and Porumbescu 2017). However, some concern has been raised about the quality of data that is collected through other online crowd-sourcing platforms, such as Mechanical Turk (MTurk) or Crowdflower (CF). In particular, the lack of naivety of participants is a growing cause for concern. A recent study in which several crowdsourcing platforms in terms of naivety and dishonesty are compared, found that participants from Prolific Academic are less dishonest and more naïve than the more commonly used MTurk (Peer et al. 2017; Palan and Schitter 2018). In addition, the quality of the data from Prolific was highest compared to MTurk and CF. Following the recommendations of this study, we expect Prolific to deliver data that meets the quality standards to test our hypotheses. 
	We will conduct our experiment among employees that work in the educational sector. More specifically, we include teachers in public primary, secondary and higher education (colleges, universities). To keep our vignettes as realistic as possible, it is necessary to take a certain work context into account. In order to make sure all participants can relate to these vignettes equally, only teachers in primary, secondary or higher educations are included in our sample. By making sure our vignettes match the work context of our participants, we increase ecological validity of our experiment (Morton and Williams 2010).

attributes.title: Person-Role Fit and Self-Esteem in Parents
attributes.description: Research has shown that the transition to parenthood is associated with changes in new parents’ self-esteem. The degree an individual’s personality fits to the demands associated with the parent role may help explain individual differences in self-esteem during the transition to parenthood. This preregistered study examines the association between personality-role fit and self-esteem in 241 first-time parents. Specifically, we examined the extent to which alignment between parents’ Big Five personality traits and their beliefs about a prototypical parent’s personality predicts levels of self-esteem while entering the parent role. We first evaluated consensus in couples’ ratings of a prototypical parent’s personality. We then used response surface analysis to test whether the correspondence between self-rated and prototypical parent personality traits predicted parent’s self-esteem assessed before and after the transition to parenthood. Discussion focuses on the relevance of person-environment fit during major life transitions.

q1.value: Person-Role Fit and Self-Esteem in Parents

q2.value: Madeline Lenhausen, Chris Hopwood, M.A. van Scheppingen, Wiebke Bleidorn

q3.value:
Theoretical Background
The transition to parenthood is a common life event that has important implications for society (Sihvonen, 2018), the parented children (Rothenberg, Weinstein, Dandes, & Jent, 2019), and parents themselves (van Scheppingen, Denissen, Chung, Tambs, & Bleidorn, 2018). Research has shown that the transition to parenthood is associated with changes in new parents’ self-esteem (Bleidorn et al., 2016). Most people, and especially women, experience small to moderate decreases in self-esteem when they become parents. However, longitudinal research has also highlighted reliable individual differences in new parents’ self-esteem change before and after the transition to parenthood. What leads to these individual differences in self-esteem during the transition to parenthood?
One possible explanation for individual differences in self-esteem during the transition to the parenthood role is that some parents may feel better suited to the demands and struggles of parenthood than others (Hutteman et al., 2014; Hutteman, Bleidorn, Penke, & Denissen, 2013). Most people, especially those who are transitioning into parenthood, may have expectations about what a prototypical parent is like. Such expectations can be described in terms of the Big Five traits emotional stability, extraversion, openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness (John, Naumann, & Soto, 2008).The degree to which parents’ own personality matches these expectations may have important implications for their self-esteem. 
These expectations are likely somewhat similar across people given the similar responsibilities associated with the parent role from person to person. For example, people may tend to believe that parents are typically high in conscientiousness, because this helps them meet the challenges and demands associated with the parent role. However, beliefs about the prototypical parent personality may also differ across people: rather than high conscientiousness, some people may view high agreeableness or high emotional stability as the most prototypical parent traits. Whether or not these beliefs are actually valid, they may be critically linked to new parents’ self-esteem as they transition to parenthood. A detail-oriented, well-organized, and responsible new parent who believes conscientiousness is important for parenthood may feel confident and experience increases in self-esteem during the transition to the parenthood role. In contrast, expecting parents who are low in this trait but believe that parents are typically high in conscientiousness may feel less confident and report diminished self-esteem because they feel their personality is not well-suited to master the demands associated with the parent role (Erol & Orth, 2011).
To date, no research has examined the prototypical personality profile associated with the parent role nor the degree to which beliefs about the match between prototypical and personal (i.e., actual, self-reported) parent personality shape new parents’ self-esteem. In this study, we plan to examine three questions related to this issue. 
First, we will identify the average Big Five profile of a prototypical parent personality and examine agreement about this profile among expecting parents. Since parenthood can be viewed as an indicator of maturity (Hutteman et al., 2014), and maturity is typically associated with increases in certain traits (Roberts & Wood, 2006), we expect the prototypical parent to be rated as having high levels of emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. However, people likely have different ideas of what the prototypical parent represents, thus we also expect differences in prototypical parent trait ratings across participants. We expect this to be the case for all traits, with the least amount of consensus for extraversion and openness, as these traits are not often referenced when discussing maturation or parenthood.
Second, we will use polynomial regression and response surface analyses (RSA; Edwards, 2002) to assess whether the correspondence between parents’ own personality and their beliefs about the prototypical parent’s personality is associated with their levels of self-esteem. We will estimate separate models for each of the Big Five traits and each model will include three variables: a parent’s rating of their own personal trait level, a parent’s rating of a prototypical parent’s personality trait level, and a parent’s rating of their own level of self-esteem. We expect to find that all Big Five personal trait ratings are positively related to self-esteem (Robins, Tracy, Trzesniewski, Potter, & Gosling, 2001), with the largest main effects for emotional stability and extraversion (Bleidorn et al., 2016). Moreover, we expect to find interaction effects between personal and prototypical parent trait ratings for all traits, indicating that people whose traits are more closely matched to their perceptions of the prototypical parent will have higher self-esteem (see below, for more details about RSA). We expect interaction effects to be relatively larger for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness compared to those observed for emotional stability and extraversion. The reason for this is that personal ratings of openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness alone are weakly associated with self-esteem. In other words, the match between parent trait expectations and personal ratings of openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness may be more associated with self-esteem than for emotional stability and extraversion. 
Third, using follow-up assessments of parents’ Big Five personality traits and self-esteem after the transition to parenthood, we will examine whether parents’ personality traits change in the direction of their ratings of a prototypical parent’s personality, and if interactions between personal trait ratings, prototypical parent trait ratings, and self-esteem replicate after the transition to parenthood. The demands associated with the parent role may evoke trait changes in the direction of that role (Hutteman et al., 2014; Roberts & Wood, 2006). Although research has not found mean-level tends in personality change after parenthood (van Scheppingen et al., 2016), there may be individual differences in trait change during this life transition. Such differences may reflect individual differences in new parents’ beliefs about a prototypical parent’s personality. To address this hypothesis, we will test whether the squared difference between personal traits and prototypical parent traits is smaller at the second compared to the first assessment.
Next, we will run the RSA models again with follow-up personality trait and self-esteem assessments. Given the nature of our design and sample, we will explore whether effects identified at the first assessment replicate. Although parents’ traits may change in certain trait domains after the transition to parenthood, meeting their individual role expectations may no longer be associated with their self-esteem. New parents may gain more insights into the parent role, realize that there are various ways to master the challenges associated with this role, or potentially adjust or relax their beliefs of a typical parent’s personality during the transition to parenthood. Each of these changes could be associated with diminished or less rigid expectations about the parent role than was the case prior to parenthood. Thus, there may no longer be an association between personality trait ratings and self-esteem after the transition to parenthood compared to before the transition.

q4.value:
We have 6 directional hypotheses and 1 exploratory hypothesis.
1.	There will be relative agreement about the personality trait levels of a prototypical parent for all traits.
2.	There will be stronger agreement in prototypical parent ratings of traits associated with maturation than traits that are not associated with maturation.
3.	The prototypical parent will have high levels of emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness.
4.	Higher levels of all personal Big Five traits will be associated with higher levels of self-esteem. This effect will be particularly strong for emotional stability and extraversion. 
5.	Prior to parenthood, participants whose personalities align with their perceptions of a prototypical parent will have higher self-esteem than participants whose personalities do not align with their perceptions of a prototypical parent. This effect will be strongest for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. 
6.	Parents will become more similar to their perceptions of a prototypical parent after the transition to parenthood. 
7.	We will explore whether alignment between personal trait ratings and parent trait expectations is still associated with self-esteem after the transition to parenthood for each of the five trait domains.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: For this study, we will analyze data from the parent subsample and only include participants who provided at least one wave of the Big Five Inventory (BFI) self-report (personal trait ratings) and Rosenberg’s self-esteem scale, and the Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI) of the prototypical parent (N = 226, 56% female). We used data from wave 1 (6 weeks prior to due date) and wave 2 (6 months after birth) in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: We have used this dataset in past research to examine self-other personality agreement in the BFI self-report data with respect to the developmental trajectory of traits in the total sample (parents and nonparents; Lenhausen, van Scheppingen, & Bleidorn, under review). However, we have not examined interactions between the BFI and TIPI-based prototypical parent ratings, and therefore have no direct knowledge pertinent to the hypotheses of this study.

question.value: Data for this study will come from the Transition to Parenthood Study, a 4-wave longitudinal study of first-time parents and couples without children. Recruitment took place between April and July 2014. For both subsamples with and without children, participants had to be in a romantic relationship and between 19 and 45 years old. People were asked to participate together with their romantic partner but were also allowed to participate without their partner. Parents-to-be were recruited through midwife practices, hospitals, and small businesses in the Tilburg area of the Netherlands that offered pregnancy or baby-related products and services (e.g., baby stores, yoga studios). All participants answered questionnaires at 4 measurement occasions (Wave 1-4). First-time fathers and mothers completed an online survey 6 weeks before the expected birth date of child and when their child was 6 months, 12 months, and 18 months old.

q13.value: For this study, we will analyze data from the parent subsample and only include participants who provided at least one wave of the Big Five Inventory (BFI) self-report (personal trait ratings) and Rosenberg’s self-esteem scale, and the Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI) of the prototypical parent (N = 226, 56% female). We used data from wave 1 (6 weeks prior to due date) and wave 2 (6 months after birth) in this study.

question.value:
Predictors
o	Personal trait ratings: We used the 44-item Big Five Inventory – Self Report (BFI; John, Naumann, & Soto, 2008) to assess the Big Five personality traits at waves 1 and 2. All items were answered on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = completely disagree to 5 = completely agree. 
o	Prototypical parent trait ratings: We used an adjusted version of Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI; Gosling, Rentfrow, & Swann, 2003) to measure how parents perceive the typical mother or father at wave 1. All items were the same as the original TIPI questionnaire and designed to measure the traits of the Big Five using a 7-point Likert scale format ranging from 1 = disagree strongly to 7 = agree strongly. However, instead of describing themselves (“I see myself as:”), participants described their view of a typical gender-consistent father or mother (“I see a typical father/mother as:”). For example, a mother would be asked to indicate how much she agreed with the item “I see a typical mother as dependable, self-disciplined.”
Outcomes
o	Self-Esteem: We used the 10-item Rosenberg’s Self-Esteem Scale (RSES; Rosenberg, 1965) to measure parents’ global self-esteem at waves 1 and 2. All items were answered on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = completely disagree to 5 = completely agree.

General Information 
We will conduct analyses for this study in R (R core team, 2018). For H1-H3, we will test relative and differential consensus in prototypical parent trait ratings using packages car version 3.0-5 (Fox & Weisberg, 2019) and multilevel version 2.6 (Bliese, 2016). For H4-H7, we will create response surface analysis (RSA) plots using the RSA package version 0.9.13 (Schönbrodt & Humberg, 2018) estimated though polynomial regression. We will handle missing data using full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation. Given the number of statistical tests we will perform, we will interpret p-values equal to or lower than .01 as significant. We will report exact p-values as well as 95% confidence intervals for all tests.
We have used this dataset in past research to examine self-other personality agreement in the BFI self-report data with respect to the developmental trajectory of traits in the total sample (parents and nonparents; Lenhausen, van Scheppingen, & Bleidorn, under review). However, we have not examined interactions between the BFI and TIPI-based prototypical parent ratings, and therefore have no direct knowledge pertinent to the hypotheses of this study.
Prototypical parent
First, we will use the TIPI ratings to identify the degree of consensus for each Big Five trait and the agreed upon profile of a prototypical parent. We will calculate the rwg coefficient for each trait to assess relative agreement about the personality trait levels of a prototypical parent for all traits. This coefficient calculates the proportion of observed variance over the variance in random ratings, subtracted from 1 (James, Demaree, & Wolf, 1984). We will interpret rwg < .30 as poor agreement whereas rwg > .50 will indicate moderate to strong agreement (LeBreton & Senter, 2008). We expect all five coefficients to be > .30 (H1).
We expect to find greater consensus for emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness (H2). We will test whether the rwg  values for emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness are significantly higher than the rwg  values for extraversion and openness by comparing confidence intervals of the rwg  value for each trait (Cohen, Doveh, & Eick, 2001; Cohen, Doveh, & Nahum-Shani, 2009). Specifically, a distribution of rwg  is created by repeatedly drawing random samples. This distribution will be used to calculate confidence intervals for each trait. Moreover, we expect this consensus will reflect the prototypical parent having high levels of emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness (H3). Thus, we will test whether trait ratings for emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness are significantly higher than openness and extraversion.
Response Surface Analysis
Second, we will construct RSA plots estimated from polynomial regression models to assess whether the correspondence between parents’ own personality and their beliefs about the prototypical parent’s personality is associated with their levels of self-esteem at wave 1. In this equation, self-esteem is the dependent variable and personal and prototypical parent trait ratings are the independent variables (Figure 1). The regression equation for these models includes linear terms for personal (b1) and prototypical trait ratings (b2), quadratic terms for both personal (b3) and prototypical (b5) trait ratings, and the linear interaction between variables (b4). We will run model comparison tests using Akaike information criteria (AIC) to compare fits of nested models. First, we will run the full model including linear and quadratic terms for each level and the interaction term between personal and prototypical parent ratings. Then, we will subsequently subtract terms and calculate the AIC of each nested model containing one fewer term. A higher AIC value will indicate more misfit in the model. These comparison tests will allow us to ascertain the terms that best explain the data. 
RSA plots visualize the results of these models as a surface in a three-dimensional coordinate system. The three-dimensional surface in RSA can be described by 5 coefficients that are calculated using the terms obtained from the polynomial regression equation: a1 = b1 + b2; a2 = b3 + b4 + b5; a3 = b1 – b2;  a4 = b3 – b4 + b5; a5 = b3 – b5. These 5 coefficients determine the line of congruence (LOC), the line of incongruence (LOIC), and the ridge line of the plotted surface. 
The LOC reflects instances where the predictor values perfectly match (e.g., a person high in conscientiousness rates high levels of conscientiousness as being prototypical of a parent’s personality); the LOIC reflects instances where the predictor variables are the exact opposite of one another (e.g., a person low in conscientiousness rates high levels of conscientiousness as being prototypical of a parent’s personality; Barranti, Carlson, & Côté, 2017). The coefficients a1 and a2 form the LOC, such that a1 represents the linear slope of the line and a2 indicates the curvilinear effect. The coefficients a3 and a4 form the LOIC, such that a3 represents the linear slope of the line and a4 indicates the curvilinear effect. The coefficient a5 represents the ridge line of the response surface (Schönbrodt, Humberg, & Nestler, 2018), indicating the optimum outcome value. In other words, this is the line on the plot where the predictor variables are associated with the highest levels of the outcome variable. 
A hypothetical RSA plot exemplifying the former terms and supporting the strict congruence hypothesis is depicted in the hypothetical response surface in Figure 2a. Strict congruence occurs when the outcome variable is consistently highest along the LOC. This surface shows people with high personal levels of a certain trait who rated that trait as being highly prototypical for a parent had the highest levels of self-esteem. Likewise, people with low personal levels of a certain trait who rated that trait as being prototypically low for a parent also had the highest levels of self-esteem In this plot, a significant negative a4 value along with nonsignificant a1 – a3 values would result in an inverted U-shaped parabola, supporting the congruence hypothesis (Humberg, Nestler, & Back, 2019). Moreover, an a5  value of 0 supports strict congruence, indicating the ridge line of the surface is located strictly on the LOC, i.e., the highest levels of self-esteem do not significantly differ from the LOC (Schönbrodt et al., 2018). Together, these values depict the optimal level of self-esteem as occurring along the LOC—the line in the plot on which personal and prototypical trait ratings perfectly match one another. Along the LOIC, people for whom personal ratings and ratings of the prototype differ (in either direction) would have lower levels of self-esteem. A looser interpretation of the congruence hypothesis also includes linear or curvilinear main effects of independent variables. In the present study, we do not expect to find strict congruence in our RSA plots as reflected in Figure 2a. Rather, we expect an amalgam of main and interaction effects for all five trait domains.
In our RSA plots, we expect to find positive main effects for all personal trait ratings on self-esteem. However, we expect personal trait ratings of emotional stability and extraversion to be stronger indicators of levels of self-esteem than personal trait ratings of openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. Specifically, we expect linear and possibly also quadratic effect sizes to be higher for personal ratings of emotional stability and extraversion than openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness.
The resulting plot we expect for mostly positive main effects is depicted in the hypothetical response surface in Figure 2b, in which higher levels of personal trait ratings predict higher self-esteem, regardless of levels of prototypical parent trait ratings. Statistically, a positive main effects model produces a significant positive a1 value and a nonsignificant a2 value, illustrating that higher levels of trait ratings are associated with higher levels of self-esteem, as opposed to equally high levels of self-esteem along the LOC. A significant positive a3 value and a significant negative a4 value would indicate that higher levels of personal trait ratings are associated with higher levels of self-esteem along the LOIC, regardless of prototypical parent trait ratings. A significant negative a5 value would indicate that the optimal level of self-esteem is significantly different than the LOC, i.e., a perfect match between both trait ratings is not associated with the highest levels of self-esteem. We will run model comparison tests to determine the terms that best explain the variance in the data (i.e., linear, quadratic, and interaction). We will then compare linear and quadratic effect sizes across traits to determine if personal trait ratings of emotional stability and extraversion are stronger predictors of self-esteem than personal trait ratings of openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. These analyses will allow us to address H4.
We expect to find interaction effects for all five trait domains on self-esteem. We expect the interaction effects for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness to support the congruence hypothesis depicted in Figure 2c. Specifically, we expect that the LOC will be associated with the highest levels of self-esteem. In this hypothetical RSA plot, people with lower personal ratings of a trait who rate that trait as being equally low for a prototypical parent still have higher levels of self-esteem than people with low personal ratings of this trait who rate a prototypical parent to be higher in this trait. We will run model comparison tests to determine if the interaction between trait ratings is significant. First, we will run the full model including linear and quadratic terms for each level and the interaction term between personal and prototypical parent ratings. Then, we will test whether deleting the interaction term would lead to a significant decrease in model fit. We expect this interaction effect to be stronger for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness than emotional stability and extraversion. We will compare interaction effect sizes across traits to determine if the interaction between trait ratings for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness is a higher predictor of self-esteem than the interaction between trait ratings for emotional stability and extraversion. These analyses will allow us to address H5.
Post-transition analyses
Third, we will use wave 1 (pre-transition) and wave 2 (post-transition) personal trait ratings with wave 1 prototypical parent ratings to assess if match between reports increases after the transition to parenthood. Specifically, we will compare the squared differences between personal trait ratings at wave 1/ wave 2 and prototypical parent trait ratings at wave 1 for each of the five trait domains using dependent t-tests. A significant decrease in the squared differences between wave 1 and wave 2 would suggest a significant increase in congruence after the transition to parenthood. This analysis will allow us to address H6.

q21.value: Given the number of statistical tests we will perform, we will interpret p-values equal to or lower than .01 as significant. We will report exact p-values as well as 95% confidence intervals for all tests.

q23.value: We will handle missing data using full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation.

q24.value: Fourth, we will rerun the polynomial regression for each of the five trait domains with RSA models to explore whether correspondence between personal personality and a prototypical parent personality is still associated with self-esteem after the transition to parenthood. We will use wave 2 of Big Five personal ratings, wave 2 self-esteem ratings, and wave 1 prototypical parent ratings. We will run the full model including linear and quadratic terms for each level and the interaction term between personal and prototypical parent ratings. A significant interaction term would indicate that match between personal ratings and prototypical parent ratings is associated with self-esteem after the transition to parenthood. These analyses will allow us to address H7.

registration_responses.q2: Madeline Lenhausen, Chris Hopwood, M.A. van Scheppingen, Wiebke Bleidorn
registration_responses.q3:
Theoretical Background
The transition to parenthood is a common life event that has important implications for society (Sihvonen, 2018), the parented children (Rothenberg, Weinstein, Dandes, & Jent, 2019), and parents themselves (van Scheppingen, Denissen, Chung, Tambs, & Bleidorn, 2018). Research has shown that the transition to parenthood is associated with changes in new parents’ self-esteem (Bleidorn et al., 2016). Most people, and especially women, experience small to moderate decreases in self-esteem when they become parents. However, longitudinal research has also highlighted reliable individual differences in new parents’ self-esteem change before and after the transition to parenthood. What leads to these individual differences in self-esteem during the transition to parenthood?
One possible explanation for individual differences in self-esteem during the transition to the parenthood role is that some parents may feel better suited to the demands and struggles of parenthood than others (Hutteman et al., 2014; Hutteman, Bleidorn, Penke, & Denissen, 2013). Most people, especially those who are transitioning into parenthood, may have expectations about what a prototypical parent is like. Such expectations can be described in terms of the Big Five traits emotional stability, extraversion, openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness (John, Naumann, & Soto, 2008).The degree to which parents’ own personality matches these expectations may have important implications for their self-esteem. 
These expectations are likely somewhat similar across people given the similar responsibilities associated with the parent role from person to person. For example, people may tend to believe that parents are typically high in conscientiousness, because this helps them meet the challenges and demands associated with the parent role. However, beliefs about the prototypical parent personality may also differ across people: rather than high conscientiousness, some people may view high agreeableness or high emotional stability as the most prototypical parent traits. Whether or not these beliefs are actually valid, they may be critically linked to new parents’ self-esteem as they transition to parenthood. A detail-oriented, well-organized, and responsible new parent who believes conscientiousness is important for parenthood may feel confident and experience increases in self-esteem during the transition to the parenthood role. In contrast, expecting parents who are low in this trait but believe that parents are typically high in conscientiousness may feel less confident and report diminished self-esteem because they feel their personality is not well-suited to master the demands associated with the parent role (Erol & Orth, 2011).
To date, no research has examined the prototypical personality profile associated with the parent role nor the degree to which beliefs about the match between prototypical and personal (i.e., actual, self-reported) parent personality shape new parents’ self-esteem. In this study, we plan to examine three questions related to this issue. 
First, we will identify the average Big Five profile of a prototypical parent personality and examine agreement about this profile among expecting parents. Since parenthood can be viewed as an indicator of maturity (Hutteman et al., 2014), and maturity is typically associated with increases in certain traits (Roberts & Wood, 2006), we expect the prototypical parent to be rated as having high levels of emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. However, people likely have different ideas of what the prototypical parent represents, thus we also expect differences in prototypical parent trait ratings across participants. We expect this to be the case for all traits, with the least amount of consensus for extraversion and openness, as these traits are not often referenced when discussing maturation or parenthood.
Second, we will use polynomial regression and response surface analyses (RSA; Edwards, 2002) to assess whether the correspondence between parents’ own personality and their beliefs about the prototypical parent’s personality is associated with their levels of self-esteem. We will estimate separate models for each of the Big Five traits and each model will include three variables: a parent’s rating of their own personal trait level, a parent’s rating of a prototypical parent’s personality trait level, and a parent’s rating of their own level of self-esteem. We expect to find that all Big Five personal trait ratings are positively related to self-esteem (Robins, Tracy, Trzesniewski, Potter, & Gosling, 2001), with the largest main effects for emotional stability and extraversion (Bleidorn et al., 2016). Moreover, we expect to find interaction effects between personal and prototypical parent trait ratings for all traits, indicating that people whose traits are more closely matched to their perceptions of the prototypical parent will have higher self-esteem (see below, for more details about RSA). We expect interaction effects to be relatively larger for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness compared to those observed for emotional stability and extraversion. The reason for this is that personal ratings of openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness alone are weakly associated with self-esteem. In other words, the match between parent trait expectations and personal ratings of openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness may be more associated with self-esteem than for emotional stability and extraversion. 
Third, using follow-up assessments of parents’ Big Five personality traits and self-esteem after the transition to parenthood, we will examine whether parents’ personality traits change in the direction of their ratings of a prototypical parent’s personality, and if interactions between personal trait ratings, prototypical parent trait ratings, and self-esteem replicate after the transition to parenthood. The demands associated with the parent role may evoke trait changes in the direction of that role (Hutteman et al., 2014; Roberts & Wood, 2006). Although research has not found mean-level tends in personality change after parenthood (van Scheppingen et al., 2016), there may be individual differences in trait change during this life transition. Such differences may reflect individual differences in new parents’ beliefs about a prototypical parent’s personality. To address this hypothesis, we will test whether the squared difference between personal traits and prototypical parent traits is smaller at the second compared to the first assessment.
Next, we will run the RSA models again with follow-up personality trait and self-esteem assessments. Given the nature of our design and sample, we will explore whether effects identified at the first assessment replicate. Although parents’ traits may change in certain trait domains after the transition to parenthood, meeting their individual role expectations may no longer be associated with their self-esteem. New parents may gain more insights into the parent role, realize that there are various ways to master the challenges associated with this role, or potentially adjust or relax their beliefs of a typical parent’s personality during the transition to parenthood. Each of these changes could be associated with diminished or less rigid expectations about the parent role than was the case prior to parenthood. Thus, there may no longer be an association between personality trait ratings and self-esteem after the transition to parenthood compared to before the transition.
registration_responses.q4:
We have 6 directional hypotheses and 1 exploratory hypothesis.
1.	There will be relative agreement about the personality trait levels of a prototypical parent for all traits.
2.	There will be stronger agreement in prototypical parent ratings of traits associated with maturation than traits that are not associated with maturation.
3.	The prototypical parent will have high levels of emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness.
4.	Higher levels of all personal Big Five traits will be associated with higher levels of self-esteem. This effect will be particularly strong for emotional stability and extraversion. 
5.	Prior to parenthood, participants whose personalities align with their perceptions of a prototypical parent will have higher self-esteem than participants whose personalities do not align with their perceptions of a prototypical parent. This effect will be strongest for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. 
6.	Parents will become more similar to their perceptions of a prototypical parent after the transition to parenthood. 
7.	We will explore whether alignment between personal trait ratings and parent trait expectations is still associated with self-esteem after the transition to parenthood for each of the five trait domains.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: We have used this dataset in past research to examine self-other personality agreement in the BFI self-report data with respect to the developmental trajectory of traits in the total sample (parents and nonparents; Lenhausen, van Scheppingen, & Bleidorn, under review). However, we have not examined interactions between the BFI and TIPI-based prototypical parent ratings, and therefore have no direct knowledge pertinent to the hypotheses of this study.
registration_responses.q13: For this study, we will analyze data from the parent subsample and only include participants who provided at least one wave of the Big Five Inventory (BFI) self-report (personal trait ratings) and Rosenberg’s self-esteem scale, and the Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI) of the prototypical parent (N = 226, 56% female). We used data from wave 1 (6 weeks prior to due date) and wave 2 (6 months after birth) in this study.
registration_responses.q21: Given the number of statistical tests we will perform, we will interpret p-values equal to or lower than .01 as significant. We will report exact p-values as well as 95% confidence intervals for all tests.
registration_responses.q23: We will handle missing data using full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation.
registration_responses.q24: Fourth, we will rerun the polynomial regression for each of the five trait domains with RSA models to explore whether correspondence between personal personality and a prototypical parent personality is still associated with self-esteem after the transition to parenthood. We will use wave 2 of Big Five personal ratings, wave 2 self-esteem ratings, and wave 1 prototypical parent ratings. We will run the full model including linear and quadratic terms for each level and the interaction term between personal and prototypical parent ratings. A significant interaction term would indicate that match between personal ratings and prototypical parent ratings is associated with self-esteem after the transition to parenthood. These analyses will allow us to address H7.

registration_responses.q8.question: For this study, we will analyze data from the parent subsample and only include participants who provided at least one wave of the Big Five Inventory (BFI) self-report (personal trait ratings) and Rosenberg’s self-esteem scale, and the Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI) of the prototypical parent (N = 226, 56% female). We used data from wave 1 (6 weeks prior to due date) and wave 2 (6 months after birth) in this study.
registration_responses.q12.question: Data for this study will come from the Transition to Parenthood Study, a 4-wave longitudinal study of first-time parents and couples without children. Recruitment took place between April and July 2014. For both subsamples with and without children, participants had to be in a romantic relationship and between 19 and 45 years old. People were asked to participate together with their romantic partner but were also allowed to participate without their partner. Parents-to-be were recruited through midwife practices, hospitals, and small businesses in the Tilburg area of the Netherlands that offered pregnancy or baby-related products and services (e.g., baby stores, yoga studios). All participants answered questionnaires at 4 measurement occasions (Wave 1-4). First-time fathers and mothers completed an online survey 6 weeks before the expected birth date of child and when their child was 6 months, 12 months, and 18 months old.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Predictors
o	Personal trait ratings: We used the 44-item Big Five Inventory – Self Report (BFI; John, Naumann, & Soto, 2008) to assess the Big Five personality traits at waves 1 and 2. All items were answered on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = completely disagree to 5 = completely agree. 
o	Prototypical parent trait ratings: We used an adjusted version of Ten Item Personality Inventory (TIPI; Gosling, Rentfrow, & Swann, 2003) to measure how parents perceive the typical mother or father at wave 1. All items were the same as the original TIPI questionnaire and designed to measure the traits of the Big Five using a 7-point Likert scale format ranging from 1 = disagree strongly to 7 = agree strongly. However, instead of describing themselves (“I see myself as:”), participants described their view of a typical gender-consistent father or mother (“I see a typical father/mother as:”). For example, a mother would be asked to indicate how much she agreed with the item “I see a typical mother as dependable, self-disciplined.”
Outcomes
o	Self-Esteem: We used the 10-item Rosenberg’s Self-Esteem Scale (RSES; Rosenberg, 1965) to measure parents’ global self-esteem at waves 1 and 2. All items were answered on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = completely disagree to 5 = completely agree.
registration_responses.q19.question:
General Information 
We will conduct analyses for this study in R (R core team, 2018). For H1-H3, we will test relative and differential consensus in prototypical parent trait ratings using packages car version 3.0-5 (Fox & Weisberg, 2019) and multilevel version 2.6 (Bliese, 2016). For H4-H7, we will create response surface analysis (RSA) plots using the RSA package version 0.9.13 (Schönbrodt & Humberg, 2018) estimated though polynomial regression. We will handle missing data using full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation. Given the number of statistical tests we will perform, we will interpret p-values equal to or lower than .01 as significant. We will report exact p-values as well as 95% confidence intervals for all tests.
We have used this dataset in past research to examine self-other personality agreement in the BFI self-report data with respect to the developmental trajectory of traits in the total sample (parents and nonparents; Lenhausen, van Scheppingen, & Bleidorn, under review). However, we have not examined interactions between the BFI and TIPI-based prototypical parent ratings, and therefore have no direct knowledge pertinent to the hypotheses of this study.
Prototypical parent
First, we will use the TIPI ratings to identify the degree of consensus for each Big Five trait and the agreed upon profile of a prototypical parent. We will calculate the rwg coefficient for each trait to assess relative agreement about the personality trait levels of a prototypical parent for all traits. This coefficient calculates the proportion of observed variance over the variance in random ratings, subtracted from 1 (James, Demaree, & Wolf, 1984). We will interpret rwg < .30 as poor agreement whereas rwg > .50 will indicate moderate to strong agreement (LeBreton & Senter, 2008). We expect all five coefficients to be > .30 (H1).
We expect to find greater consensus for emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness (H2). We will test whether the rwg  values for emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness are significantly higher than the rwg  values for extraversion and openness by comparing confidence intervals of the rwg  value for each trait (Cohen, Doveh, & Eick, 2001; Cohen, Doveh, & Nahum-Shani, 2009). Specifically, a distribution of rwg  is created by repeatedly drawing random samples. This distribution will be used to calculate confidence intervals for each trait. Moreover, we expect this consensus will reflect the prototypical parent having high levels of emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness (H3). Thus, we will test whether trait ratings for emotional stability, agreeableness, and conscientiousness are significantly higher than openness and extraversion.
Response Surface Analysis
Second, we will construct RSA plots estimated from polynomial regression models to assess whether the correspondence between parents’ own personality and their beliefs about the prototypical parent’s personality is associated with their levels of self-esteem at wave 1. In this equation, self-esteem is the dependent variable and personal and prototypical parent trait ratings are the independent variables (Figure 1). The regression equation for these models includes linear terms for personal (b1) and prototypical trait ratings (b2), quadratic terms for both personal (b3) and prototypical (b5) trait ratings, and the linear interaction between variables (b4). We will run model comparison tests using Akaike information criteria (AIC) to compare fits of nested models. First, we will run the full model including linear and quadratic terms for each level and the interaction term between personal and prototypical parent ratings. Then, we will subsequently subtract terms and calculate the AIC of each nested model containing one fewer term. A higher AIC value will indicate more misfit in the model. These comparison tests will allow us to ascertain the terms that best explain the data. 
RSA plots visualize the results of these models as a surface in a three-dimensional coordinate system. The three-dimensional surface in RSA can be described by 5 coefficients that are calculated using the terms obtained from the polynomial regression equation: a1 = b1 + b2; a2 = b3 + b4 + b5; a3 = b1 – b2;  a4 = b3 – b4 + b5; a5 = b3 – b5. These 5 coefficients determine the line of congruence (LOC), the line of incongruence (LOIC), and the ridge line of the plotted surface. 
The LOC reflects instances where the predictor values perfectly match (e.g., a person high in conscientiousness rates high levels of conscientiousness as being prototypical of a parent’s personality); the LOIC reflects instances where the predictor variables are the exact opposite of one another (e.g., a person low in conscientiousness rates high levels of conscientiousness as being prototypical of a parent’s personality; Barranti, Carlson, & Côté, 2017). The coefficients a1 and a2 form the LOC, such that a1 represents the linear slope of the line and a2 indicates the curvilinear effect. The coefficients a3 and a4 form the LOIC, such that a3 represents the linear slope of the line and a4 indicates the curvilinear effect. The coefficient a5 represents the ridge line of the response surface (Schönbrodt, Humberg, & Nestler, 2018), indicating the optimum outcome value. In other words, this is the line on the plot where the predictor variables are associated with the highest levels of the outcome variable. 
A hypothetical RSA plot exemplifying the former terms and supporting the strict congruence hypothesis is depicted in the hypothetical response surface in Figure 2a. Strict congruence occurs when the outcome variable is consistently highest along the LOC. This surface shows people with high personal levels of a certain trait who rated that trait as being highly prototypical for a parent had the highest levels of self-esteem. Likewise, people with low personal levels of a certain trait who rated that trait as being prototypically low for a parent also had the highest levels of self-esteem In this plot, a significant negative a4 value along with nonsignificant a1 – a3 values would result in an inverted U-shaped parabola, supporting the congruence hypothesis (Humberg, Nestler, & Back, 2019). Moreover, an a5  value of 0 supports strict congruence, indicating the ridge line of the surface is located strictly on the LOC, i.e., the highest levels of self-esteem do not significantly differ from the LOC (Schönbrodt et al., 2018). Together, these values depict the optimal level of self-esteem as occurring along the LOC—the line in the plot on which personal and prototypical trait ratings perfectly match one another. Along the LOIC, people for whom personal ratings and ratings of the prototype differ (in either direction) would have lower levels of self-esteem. A looser interpretation of the congruence hypothesis also includes linear or curvilinear main effects of independent variables. In the present study, we do not expect to find strict congruence in our RSA plots as reflected in Figure 2a. Rather, we expect an amalgam of main and interaction effects for all five trait domains.
In our RSA plots, we expect to find positive main effects for all personal trait ratings on self-esteem. However, we expect personal trait ratings of emotional stability and extraversion to be stronger indicators of levels of self-esteem than personal trait ratings of openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. Specifically, we expect linear and possibly also quadratic effect sizes to be higher for personal ratings of emotional stability and extraversion than openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness.
The resulting plot we expect for mostly positive main effects is depicted in the hypothetical response surface in Figure 2b, in which higher levels of personal trait ratings predict higher self-esteem, regardless of levels of prototypical parent trait ratings. Statistically, a positive main effects model produces a significant positive a1 value and a nonsignificant a2 value, illustrating that higher levels of trait ratings are associated with higher levels of self-esteem, as opposed to equally high levels of self-esteem along the LOC. A significant positive a3 value and a significant negative a4 value would indicate that higher levels of personal trait ratings are associated with higher levels of self-esteem along the LOIC, regardless of prototypical parent trait ratings. A significant negative a5 value would indicate that the optimal level of self-esteem is significantly different than the LOC, i.e., a perfect match between both trait ratings is not associated with the highest levels of self-esteem. We will run model comparison tests to determine the terms that best explain the variance in the data (i.e., linear, quadratic, and interaction). We will then compare linear and quadratic effect sizes across traits to determine if personal trait ratings of emotional stability and extraversion are stronger predictors of self-esteem than personal trait ratings of openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. These analyses will allow us to address H4.
We expect to find interaction effects for all five trait domains on self-esteem. We expect the interaction effects for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness to support the congruence hypothesis depicted in Figure 2c. Specifically, we expect that the LOC will be associated with the highest levels of self-esteem. In this hypothetical RSA plot, people with lower personal ratings of a trait who rate that trait as being equally low for a prototypical parent still have higher levels of self-esteem than people with low personal ratings of this trait who rate a prototypical parent to be higher in this trait. We will run model comparison tests to determine if the interaction between trait ratings is significant. First, we will run the full model including linear and quadratic terms for each level and the interaction term between personal and prototypical parent ratings. Then, we will test whether deleting the interaction term would lead to a significant decrease in model fit. We expect this interaction effect to be stronger for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness than emotional stability and extraversion. We will compare interaction effect sizes across traits to determine if the interaction between trait ratings for openness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness is a higher predictor of self-esteem than the interaction between trait ratings for emotional stability and extraversion. These analyses will allow us to address H5.
Post-transition analyses
Third, we will use wave 1 (pre-transition) and wave 2 (post-transition) personal trait ratings with wave 1 prototypical parent ratings to assess if match between reports increases after the transition to parenthood. Specifically, we will compare the squared differences between personal trait ratings at wave 1/ wave 2 and prototypical parent trait ratings at wave 1 for each of the five trait domains using dependent t-tests. A significant decrease in the squared differences between wave 1 and wave 2 would suggest a significant increase in congruence after the transition to parenthood. This analysis will allow us to address H6.
